x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.problem_statement: Millions of patients worldwide struggle with low health literacy, meaning they can't understand the medications they are prescribed — how to take them, what they are for, or what side effects to expect. This is especially common in underserved, multilingual, or low-income communities, where printed leaflets are ineffective, and clinical staff may be too overloaded to provide one-on-one guidance. As a result, patients misuse medications, skip doses, or abandon treatment altogether, leading to complications and hospital readmissions.

x_snc_hack4good_0_hack4good_proposal.solution_proposal:
How do you envision the ideal solution to this  problem?

 

Which ServiceNow products or capabilities would be used?

PharmaEdu AI is an AI-powered medical education assistant built with ServiceNow's AI Agent that provides simple, personalized medication guidance in a patient’s preferred language and learning style.

Key features include:

1) Patients or clinic staff input a prescription or scan a medication label
2) The AI Agent explains what the medicine is for, how and when to take it, and possible side effects
3) Guidance is provided via voice, text, and visual aids (e.g., images or symbols)
4) Supports multiple languages (e.g., English, Hindi, Spanish, Swahili)
5) Can be accessed via mobile, kiosk, or embedded in patient portals

Uses conversational workflows to answer follow-up questions like:

“Can I take this with food?” or “What if I miss a dose?”

Ideal for NGOs, rural clinics, pharmacies, and health programs serving low-literacy populations.

 

Are there any technical dependencies for the proposed solution?

1) AI Agent – Core capability to deliver multilingual, intelligent, and natural conversations
2) Virtual Agent Designer – To build guided education flows and support visual assets
3) ServiceNow App Engine – For managing medicine database, patient interactions, and feedback
4) IntegrationHub – To connect with medicine information sources (e.g., MedlinePlus, WHO, RxNorm APIs)
5) Service Portal – Interface for patients or healthcare workers in clinics or kiosks
6) Performance Analytics – To track usage, languages served, and patient satisfaction

Technical dependencies -
1) Access to verified, multilingual drug information databases
2) Speech-to-text and text-to-speech services for voice interaction
3) Local language support for content generation and translation
4) Mobile/tablet-friendly UI with offline capabilities for remote areas
5) Ability to upload or connect to prescription info from clinic systems

 

What challenges would you foresee in implementing this idea?

  • Ensuring accuracy and safety of AI-generated content
  • Creating culturally appropriate and locally relevant explanations
  • Voice support in less-common languages or dialects
  • Ensuring low bandwidth compatibility and offline fallback for rural clinics
  • Balancing simplicity with clinical completeness in explanations
